I'm 4 months late, but this is how I did it.   1) Get the first and last coefficients (15 and 16) and find the prime factors. for 15 they are 5, 3, 1, and for 16 they are 2, 2, 2, 2, 1. The set of possible roots we are looking for is made from making unique positive or negative fractions with factors of 16 on top and 15 on the bottom. These are +- 1/5, +- 2/5, +- 1/3, +- 2/3, +- 1 and +- 2.   2) Now you do synthetic division checking some of the possible answers. Its easier to start with the whole numbers, like -2 or 1. If you do it for -2 you will find it is one of the answers. The equation is now (x + 2)(15x^3 - 29x^2 + 6x + 8).   3) When one of the possible answers is 1, there is a trick we can use to quickly see if it is an answer. If the coefficients sum to 0, that means 1 is an answer. 15 - 29 + 6 + 8 = 0, so that means 1 is the next answer. We still want to do the synthetic division with 1, just to get the new coefficients (at least that's how I did it). Now we have (x + 2)(x - 1)(15x^2 - 14x -8).  4) Since our highest degree is now 2, we can let 15, -14 and -8 be a, b, c and plug them into the quadratic formula. This will show that the final two answers are 4/3 and -2/5.   5) Therefore, x = -2, 1, 4/3, -2/5  Hope this helped.
Great explanation

@blackironanimationfilmb.a.4165  You can substitute in all possible rational solutions to the polynomial, and use trial and error to identify them.  This could give you all the solutions you need.  However, this method will only work to find all the solutions, if all the solutions are rational real numbers in the first place.  If there is a mixture of rational roots and irrational roots, then you'd first find the rational roots with the rational root theorem and trial and error.  Then you'd need to use polynomial division to reduce the polynomial, in order to find the irrational roots.  He deliberately set up his examples, so that he could reduce it to a quadratic to find the irrational roots, and that is the only case where you can find irrational roots that are simple roots of an integer.  Higher degree cases like irreducible cubics, will likely have nested messes of square roots inside cube roots, and possibly even complex numbers that add up to real numbers (in ways that aren't even remotely obvious).
​ @carultch thanks again

If you exhaust all possible rational solutions, then there are no rational roots.  For cubic and quartic equations, there are equivalents of the quadratic formula, that would allow you to analytically calculate the roots, but these formulas are rarely taught outside a math degree, as they are difficult to use, and require a detour to complex numbers to find the real solutions in many cases.   For quintics and higher, Galois proved that it is impossible for such a formula using algebraic operations to even exist.  A brief overview of the cubic formula: Step 1: Divide through by a, to make it monic Step 2: Do a change of variables to shift it horizontally, so the second term reduces to zero.  This and step 1, allow us to reduce any cubic from a*x^3 + b*x^2 + c*x + d, to the form of t^3 + p*x + q.   The constants p and q will both equal expressions that combine the original constants a/b/c/d. Step 3: find the discriminant, capital D.  D = p^3/27 + q^2/4.  If D is positive, there is just one real solution.  If D is negative, there will be 3 real solutions, which will either require a detour to the complex numbers to find, or use of the trigonometric cubic formula.  If D is zero, this means we have at least one repeated real root. Step 4: use the reduced cubic formula, t = cbrt(-q/2 + sqrt(D)) + cbrt(-q/2 - sqrt(D))  When D is positive, this will find the one real solution.  Example to try: t^3 - 15*t - 126.  When D is zero, this will find the distinct real solution.  Example to try: t^3 - 12*t + 16 You could detour to the complex roots of each cbrt() term, which will be a conjugate pair in both cases, that add up to the remaining solution.  Or use the distinct real solution with polynomial division, to find the quadratic with a repeated root.  D can also equal zero in the trivial case where both p=0 and q=0, which will mean a thrice-repeated solution of t=0.  When D is negative, you'll have cube roots of complex numbers, that themselves are complex.  Example to try: t^3 - 6*t + 4 There will be 3 cube roots of the first expression, and 3 cube roots of the second expression.   Among all of them, there will be three conjugate pairs that add up to the 3 real solutions.

In other words, suppose the polynomial has the form: a*x^n + b*x^(n - 1) + .... + k  n is the degree of the polynomial, i.e. the highest exponent on x a is the coefficient on the first term b is the coefficient on the second term k is the final constant term, that doesn't contain any x's.  It's just a constant.  In other words, it's the y-intercept.  If you had a polynomial greater than degree 10, you'd have to come up with another set of letters to name it, but I'll call it k, so it can apply to most examples you'd likely do.
​ @carultch thankss
Perhaps, that's what it means to be a real mathematician (I gave up after 2 attempts)

If there is no constant term, then that means zero is guaranteed to be one of the solutions, and it is a trivial step to factor out a single instance of x from each term.  This then reduces the polynomial that remains by at least one degree.  For example, consider x^3 - 5*x^2 + 6*x.  Factor out one instance of x, and get x*(x^2 - 5*x + 6).  Now we see right away that one of the roots is x.  The remaining polynomial can be factored as (x - 2)*(x - 3), allowing us to see that the other two solutions are x=2 and x=3.

He probably set this up deliberately, from known factors that he wanted his example polynomials to have.  And he didn't want to waste time showing you the dead-end guesses that don't end up working, so he started with the known solutions.  The rational root theorem tells you what you have as candidates for rational solutions to the polynomial equaling zero.  You select from those candidates, and use trial and error to determine which ones are roots to the polynomial.  Not all of them will be, so this is all strategic trial and error.  You can also use the signs as clues to the signs of the roots.  If there are only positive signs on all terms, this means that most of your roots will be negative.  And if you do have a positive root, it will have an equal and opposite negative root.   The roots also must add up to -b/a (where a and b are the first and second coefficients respectively), and multiply to k/a*(-1)^n, where k is the final constant and (-1)^n is an alternator that is positive for even degree polynomials, and negative for odd degree polynomials.  This works as clues to tell you which solutions are more likely to work.

Given any polynomial in the form of: a*x^n + b*x^(n-1) + c*x^(n-2) + ... + k  where n is the degree of the polynomial, a is the leading coefficient, b is the next coefficient, k is the final constant term, and the triple dots are remaining terms that aren't relevant to my point.  It's solutions will add up to -b/a, and multiply to k/a*(-1)^n.   The (-1)^n is an alternator, that makes it positive for even degree polynomials, and negative for odd degree polynomials.  So the b-term is a clue to the sum of the roots, and k is a clue to the product of the roots.  You can show why this works, by composing a polynomial from factored form.  I'll use capital letters to represent its roots. a*(x - A)*(x - B)*(x - C)*(x - D)  When you expand it, and gather based on the common power of x, the first term will be a*x^4, and the second term will be -a*(A+B+C+D)*x^3.   The final term will be a*A*B*C*D.  If you do this with a cubic, a*(x - A)*(x - B)*(x - C), you'll get a similar result.  The first term will be a*x^3, the second term will be -a*(A+B+C)*x^2, and the final term will be -a*A*B*C.  Since there are an odd number of negative signs among all the binomial factor, this means the final term is negative, given all positive roots.
In that case you know that a root must be 0 and you can factor an X to continue the algorithm

Because 1 is the multiplicative identity, and is a factor of every integer.   It's a trivial a factor, but it is a still a constant factor nonetheless, and it is part of this strategy for finding the rational roots.

@zafnaahmed3352  He probably planned his examples, using the factored form and then expanding.  So he knew in advance which solutions to try.

Given: x^4 + 2x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x + 1 = 0  Perform a quartic shift to eliminate the 2x^3 term.   Define t such that x = t - 1/2, which will eliminate the x^3 term. (t - 1/2)^4+2*(t - 1/2)^3+3*(t - 1/2)^2+2*(t - 1/2)+1=0  Expand and simplify: t^4 + 3/2*t^2 + 9/16 = 0  As you can see, all odd-powered values are now eliminated, and we only have even powers of t.   Let u = t^2, and rewrite in terms of u: u^2 + 3/2*u + 9/16 = 0  Which we can use the quadratic formula to solve for u: u = (-(3/2) +/- sqrt(9/4 - 4*9/16))/2  Both solutions are u = -3/4, since the square root term simplifies to zero.  This means t = +/- i*sqrt(3)/2  And undo the shift, by subtracting 1/2: x = -1/2 +/- i*sqrt(3)/2  These are two repeated solutions, that are a complex conjugate pair.

If you exhaust all possible rational solutions, then you'd have to use the cubic or quartic formula, whichever is applicable.  These are higher degree counterparts to the quadratic formula, although they are complicated and often require a detour to the complex numbers to use.  If it is a quintic or anything beyond, then there is no such formula, as proven by Galois.  You'd probably have to use Newton's method to approximate the roots.

I apologize if I strike a sour note if I question the utility of this material.  I'm a crusty old retired engineer. I can confidently state that these techniques are next to useless in the real world, unless you're stranded on a desert island perhaps.  Clearly then they can be of only pedagogic interest.  On an exam you may be asked to apply them. Back when I was an engineering student the course was already crammed to the gills with a wide range of topics, most of which proved useless in my subsequent career.  At the time they served the function of an obstacle course in which only the tough survive. The same thing must be at work in academic mathematics programs - only the most dedicated will survive.  With both engineering and mathematics expanding in scope year by year it becomes a necessity at some point to specialize or narrow the scope of courses. Frankly, although this material is ingenious, it does smack a bit of rote learning.  Let's face it if in a subsequent career one is faced with solving polynomials in the higher degrees there are quicker and more practical means at our disposal. There is a master formula for quadratics, cubics, and quartics, but quartics are the end of the line.  Galois proved that there can be no quintic formula, or anything beyond, if you are limited to arithmetic, powers, roots, exponentials, logarithms, and trigonometry.  In special cases, it is possible to extract the roots of a higher degree polynomial, despite no such formula existing, but only in those special cases.  Such as triquadratic 6th degree equations, where you can simply replace x^3 with w, and solve for w.  You can also use the rational roots theorem and trial and error, if you are lucky enough to have a rational root.  I can refer you to Mathologer's video on how to make sense of the cubic formula, which I've mastered after exploring on my own with his help.  He also reveals the quartic formula at the end, but I've yet to make sense of it. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N-KXStupwsc

If there is no constant term, there is a trivial root of x=0.  You can simply factor out an x from each term, and reduce the polynomial by 1 degree, until you get a polynomial with a constant term at the end.

​ @ssrijan03  This method only works when there is at least one rational root.  There do exist formulas to solve cubics and quartics, but they are complicated, and are seldom taught outside a math degree.  I've used the cubic formula before, and it is not that difficult to make sense of, and it is something that probably should be taught in high school math, even just as a simple introduction without testing students on it.  The quartic formula by contrast is a lot more challenging to use.  You are probably better off using Newton's method to approximate the roots, for any practical application.  Or use Wolfram Alpha, which has this formula programmed into it.

Because a trivial step in solving polynomials, is to divide through by the leading constant of a, and making the entire polynomial, a monic polynomial where the coefficient on the highest power of x is 1. Are u Shannon Gabriel?

The answer is yes.  Once you reduce a higher degree polynomial to a quadratic, you can use the quadratic formula to find its roots that are part of the quadratic factor.  The reason the rational roots test works, is that for polynomials in general in the following form, the roots will all multiply to k/a for even degree polynomials, and -k/a for odd degree polynomials. a*x^n + b*x^(n - 1) + ... other terms ... + k  To figure out why it works, consider the general polynomial factored as: a*(x - r1)*(x - r2)*(x - r3)*....*(x - rn)  When you expand it out, the final constant term will equal: a*product -r_m, from m=1 to n =  a*-r1*-r2*-r3*...*-rn  If there are an even number of roots, there are an even number of minus signs, which render this term to have the same sign as the product of roots. If there are an odd number of roots, then there are an odd number of minus signs, which will render this term to be opposite in sign as the product of roots.
Same thought

@kaushikbarui6953   If you exhaust all possible rational solutions, then you'd have to use the cubic or quartic formula, whichever is applicable.  These are higher degree counterparts to the quadratic formula, although they are complicated and often require a detour to the complex numbers to use.  If it is a quintic or anything beyond, then there is no such formula, as proven by Galois.  You'd probably have to use Newton's method to approximate the roots.
